snippet: The higher costs on rent-stabilized apartments in New York City, which will be finalized after public hearings in June, were comparable to those voted on last year.
abstract: New York City Rent Guidelines Board votes to recommend increases of 1.75 percent to 4 percent on one-year leases, and 3.5 percent to 6.75 percent on two-year leases, for rent-stabilized apartments; increases will be narrowed to a single percentage point and finalized after public hearings in June. (M)
lead_paragraph: A panel voted on Tuesday to recommend raising rents on rent-stabilized apartments in New York City by amounts comparable to those approved last year. By a vote of 5 to 4 at Cooper Union's Great Hall, the Rent Guidelines Board approved increases of 1.75 percent to 4 percent on one-year leases, and 3.5 percent to 6.75 percent increases on two-year leases.

headline.main: Board Is Met With Jeers as It Recommends an Increase in Rents
